t: Proverbs 6
Practical Warnings
My*pn son, if you have put up security for your neighbor, have*ld given your pledge for a stranger,
if*ln you are snared in the words of your mouth, caught*ld in the words of your mouth,
then*ln do this, my son, and save yourself, for*ld you have come into the hand of your neighbor: go,*ld hasten, and plead urgently with your neighbor.
Give*ln your eyes no sleep and*ld your eyelids no slumber;
save*ln yourself like a gazelle from the hand of the hunter, like*ld a bird from the hand of the fowler.
Go*pn to the ant, O sluggard; consider*ld her ways, and be wise.
Without*ln having any chief, officer,*ld or ruler,
she*ln prepares her bread in summer and*ld gathers her food in harvest.
How*ln long will you lie there, O sluggard? When*ld will you arise from your sleep?
A*ln little sleep, a little slumber, a*ld little folding of the hands to rest,
and*ln poverty will come upon you like a robber, and*ld want like an armed man.
A*pn worthless person, a wicked man, goes*ld about with crooked speech,
winks*ln with his eyes, signals with his feet, points*ld with his finger,
with*ln perverted heart devises evil, continually*ld sowing discord;
therefore*ln calamity will come upon him suddenly; in*ld a moment he will be broken beyond healing.
There*pn are six things that the Lord*s hates, seven*ld that are an abomination to him:
haughty*ln eyes, a lying tongue, and*ld hands that shed innocent blood,
a*ln heart that devises wicked plans, feet*ld that make haste to run to evil,
a*ln false witness who breathes out lies, and*ld one who sows discord among brothers.
Warnings Against Adultery
My*pn son, keep your father’s commandment, and*ld forsake not your mother’s teaching.
Bind*ln them on your heart always; tie*ld them around your neck.
When*ln you walk, they will lead you; when*ld you lie down, they will watch over you; and*ld when you awake, they will talk with you.
For*ln the commandment is a lamp and the teaching a light, and*ld the reproofs of discipline are the way of life,
to*ln preserve you from the evil woman, from*ld the smooth tongue of the adulteress.
Do*ln not desire her beauty in your heart, and*ld do not let her capture you with her eyelashes;
for*ln the price of a prostitute is only a loaf of bread, but*ld a married woman hunts down a precious life.
Can*ln a man carry fire next to his chest and*ld his clothes not be burned?
Or*ln can one walk on hot coals and*ld his feet not be scorched?
So*ln is he who goes in to his neighbor’s wife; none*ld who touches her will go unpunished.
People*ln do not despise a thief if he steals to*ld satisfy his appetite when he is hungry,
but*ln if he is caught, he will pay sevenfold; he*ld will give all the goods of his house.
He*ln who commits adultery lacks sense; he*ld who does it destroys himself.
He*ln will get wounds and dishonor, and*ld his disgrace will not be wiped away.
For*ln jealousy makes a man furious, and*ld he will not spare when he takes revenge.
He*ln will accept no compensation; he*ld will refuse though you multiply gifts.
